@jermainewang @pluskid

@butterluo Yes, ps-lite is used as distributed backend, but the interface is quite flexible to change to others when needed. The new ps-lite is quite helpful, and allows you to define custom updates through native language such as python

The name of the unspecified arguments are automatically generated. In your case

```
try to use softmax1_label and softmax2_label instead to refer to each of the input labels.
```

Alternatively, specify the name by 

``` python
label1=mx.symbol.Variable("sm1_label");
label2=mx.symbol.Variable("sm2_label");
softmax1 = mx.symbol.SoftmaxOutput(data=fc3, label=label1, name='softmax1')
softmax2 = mx.symbol.SoftmaxOutput(data=fc3, label=label2, name='softmax2')
```

please check if it works for you, it would be great if any of you are interested in contributing an example of multi-labels even a mock up on with MNIST
See https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/doc/python/io.md#extension-mutliple-labels-for-a-single-image

The metric is only used to show evalaution statistics, with nothing related to the objective function. The objective is defined by what Output node you used in the graph, such as SoftmaxOutput and RegressionOutput

Hi, could you try [numpy-level op](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/tree/master/example/numpy-ops) to do that?
What's the shape of your label tensor?

@jermainewang Following is the code I used to build a sparse connected layer

```
class SingleConnected(mx.operator.NumpyOp):
    def __init__(self):
        super(SingleConnected, self).__init__(True)

    def list_arguments(self):
        return ['data', 'weight', 'bias']

    def list_outputs(self):
        return ['output']

    def infer_shape(self, in_shape):
        data_shape = in_shape[0]
        weight_shape = (in_shape[0][1],)
        bias_shape = (in_shape[0][1],)
        output_shape = in_shape[0]
        return [data_shape, weight_shape, bias_shape], [output_shape]

    def forward(self, in_data, out_data):
        x = in_data[0]
        w = in_data[1]
        b = in_data[2]
        y = out_data[0]
        # element-wise
        y = x * w + b

    def backward(self, out_grad, in_data, out_data, in_grad):
        dx = in_grad[0]
        dw = in_grad[1]
        db = in_grad[2]
        dy = out_grad[0]
        x  = in_data[0]
        w  = in_data[1]
        dx[:] = dy * w
        dw[:] = np.sum(dy * x, axis=0)
        db[:] = np.sum(dy, axis=0)
        print 'dy', dy
```

In addition, the structure and model are defined as following

```
data = mx.symbol.Variable('data')
mySingleConnected = SingleConnected()
hh = mySingleConnected(data = data, name='hh')
fc = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data = hh, name='fc', num_hidden = 1)
mlp = mx.symbol.LinearRegressionOutput(data = fc, name = 'regression')


model = mx.model.FeedForward(
    ctx = mx.cpu(), symbol = mlp, num_epoch = 2,
    learning_rate = 0.001, momentum = 0.9, wd = 0.,
    # optimizer          = 'adam',
    initializer        = mx.init.Uniform(0.001)
)
```

I print `dy` during training, yet the printed value sometimes become `inf` or `nan`. Any ideas to solve this? Thanks!
How did you call smooth_l1_loss? BTW, I would replace 1.0f with 1.0f/sigma2
Why do you want multi_output=True if you only have one output?
Actually this is because mysoftmax gets garbage collected. keep a reference on it by returning mysoftmax together with output and it will work
Alexnet eats a lot of pcie bandwidth. We often use a much larger batchsize. The inception network is much better
You said "sometimes become inf or nan" so it's not always inf or nan? This most likely is because numerical problems in you model. e.g. some parameters/inputs are too big
@hjk41 I think require the user to build from source when using C++ api should be fine. Maintaining a complete C  API seems too much work load

@mli KVStore.create is unaware of the context being used (which is gpu) and always select 'local_allreduce_cpu' which cause gradients to be copied to CPU even for single GPU training. We should change the interface to include context
reshape final convolutional layer output to (batchsize, K,) with flatten symbol
@teng88 @sofiawu @happynear Could you describe your use case? Why do you need C++ interface and not the other language bindings? Which part of the interface do you need most?
Maybe it makes sense to expose a simplified symbolic computing interface to allow the user specify the computation graph of an optimizer conveniently?
My reason for using C++ optimizer is to avoid temp memory and finish everything in one kernel to increase speed. That kind of defeats the purpose
Probably not. Seems that solving this will have to dive into mshadow code, which is harder  ?

Regarding blas, I download the latest binary package of openblas from http://www.openblas.net/. Once you run Cmake, it will complain about not finding atlas, where you can just set BLAS to be Open; and then using the corresponding include dir and libs.
